item.title: Future Problems for Private Lending Will Start Today
item.description: More lenders chasing the same deals could sow the seeds of tomorrow’s problems.

item.title: China to Start Sale of Ultralong Bond to Support Economy
item.description: China will start selling the first batch of a planned $138.37 billion ultralong bond issuance this week, as Beijing looks to provide more support to the economy.

item.title: RBC Reorganizes Investment Banking in a Play for More Deals
item.description: The bank is naming Matthew Stopnik global investment banking head, based in New York.

item.title: Intel Nears Deal With Apollo for $11 Billion Ireland Partnership
item.description: The investment firm is in exclusive talks to supply the chip giant with cash for a new plant.

item.title: The Random Path to Stock-Market Riches
item.description: How WSJ columnists made 80% in a year without really trying.

item.title: Investors Crowd Into Soft-Landing Trade Ahead of Crucial Inflation Data
item.description: Stocks and bonds have rallied ahead of Wednesday’s consumer-price index report.

item.title: Platinum Market Deficit Forecast Widens on Weak Supply, Sustained Demand
item.description: The precious metal is now forecast for a market deficit of 476,000 ounces in 2024 amid strained supply from the mining sector and resilient demand, according to a new report from the World Platinum Investment Council.

item.title: Country Garden Avoids Further Default With Payments on Onshore Bonds
item.description: Chinese property developer Country Garden made payments on two onshore bonds within a grace period, avoiding default days after the company had said it might turn to a state guarantor for help.

item.title: Wealth Managers, Charities Defend Fees From Donor-Advised Funds
item.description: “Strange bedfellows” are teaming up to oppose a Treasury Department proposal penalizing certain payments.

item.title: What You Need to Know About Managing Expenses to Buy and Stay in Your Home
item.description: A podcast series examines sustainable homeownership by outlining the financial implications of buying a house.

item.title: What's So Bad About Fixing Oil Prices?
item.description: A U.S. oil CEO’s alleged collusion with OPEC isn’t as alarming or evil as it seems.

item.title: Wall Street Turns Up the Heat on Companies to Perform
item.description: Shares of companies that missed first-quarter earnings estimates have slid an average of 2.8%, compared with the five-year average of a 2.3% decline.

item.title: This Stock-Market Rally Isn't What It Seems
item.description: To anybody listening to Wall Street analysts, it might sound like all the market volatility has had to do with the economy and the Federal Reserve’s policy response. But what if stocks just got too expensive?

item.title: Inside the 21st Century Gold Rush
item.description: Worries about war, discord and mounting government debt have fueled a worldwide rush by individuals and institutions into what Wall Street calls “physical gold”— bars, coins, jewelry and nuggets.

item.title: The 'Save the Oceans' Tax Break: Recycling Oyster Shells
item.description: People love to eat oysters. The shells often end up in landfills. These restaurants want to repurpose them—and save some money.

item.title: How Did Jim Simons's Firm Make $100 Billion? He Told His Secrets to Our Reporter
item.description: The huge gains came both from groundbreaking insights and lots of small innovations. Being way out on Long Island didn’t hurt either.

item.title: Heard on the Street's Stock-Picking Contest
item.description: Read about our columnists’ favorite and least-favorite stocks and see how they have performed.

item.title: The Score: Tyson Foods, Walt Disney, Shopify and More Stocks That Defined the Week
item.description: Here are some of the major companies whose stocks moved on the week’s news

item.title: Stocks Log Weekly Gains in Hot Start to May
item.description: The month’s performance so far marks a reversal from April.

item.title: How to Lend Family Money Without Wrecking Your Relationship
item.description: High interest rates lead more people to borrow money from family. Tech tools can reduce the risks and grief.
